item.title: Ghost Of Yotei Seems To Have Sold Just Fine Despite Reactionary Boycott
item.content:encoded:
Ghost of Yotei was the fourth best-selling game in the U.S. for September with just three days out on the market, according to the latest figures from Circana. Sony‚Äôs latest open-world blockbuster appears to be doing just fine despite an attempted boycott by online grifters and their followers.

‚ÄúWith one week in market, the US sales performance of Ghost of Yotei was basically flat to that of Ghost of Tsushima,‚Äù the research firm‚Äôs Mat Piscatella wrote on Bluesky. ‚ÄúIt did great. Ghost of Tsushima launched in July 2020 (if you‚Äôll recall, stuff was happening at the time that significantly boosted gaming), and the PS4 installed base at the time was significantly higher than the PS5 is today. Like, anyone with ‚Äòconcern‚Äô about this title should be looked at with a side eye.‚Äù

Ghost of Yotei was behind Borderlands 4, NBA 2K26, and EA Sports FC 26, which isn‚Äôt surprising considering those are multiplatform best-sellers and the samurai revenge tale remains exclusive to PS5 right now. Sales were still enough to make Yotei the 18th best-seller of the year so far by revenue and the second best-selling game on PlayStation during the period, just behind NBA 2K26 but ahead of Borderlands 4 which had two additional weeks on the market.

Ghost of Yotei has been on the receiving end of a slow-burn reactionary backlash from online culture warriors ever since it revealed its protagonist was a woman named Atsu. She‚Äôs played by Erika Ishii who was attacked by the usual suspects for being queer and for posting about about defunding the police during the 2020 George Floyd protests. The flame war intensified after a Sucker Punch developer posted a joke about the Charlie Kirk assassination, with some calling for a boycott of Yotei even after the developer was fired for the remark. Boycott or no, it seems to have had little meaningful impact on Yotei‚Äòs trajectory, at least at launch.

Is Borderlands 4 still a sales juggernaut?

The September sales figures have some other interesting nuggets to chew on. Borderlands 4 posted some impressive Ws but with a few major caveats. It was the best-selling game in the U.S. for the month and instantly hit number three for the entire year, with 30 percent higher dollar sales at launch than Borderlands 3. But Borderlands 3 was $60 instead of $70, didn‚Äôt have a Super Deluxe Edition selling for $130, and wasn‚Äôt initially available on Steam, where Borderlands 4 appears to have sold a good portion of its copies.

2K Games hasn‚Äôt released any official sales figures yet. Borderlands 3 sold over 22 million copies and before that, Borderlands 2 hit 30 million. My guess is that Borderlands 4, a return to form hampered somewhat by PC issues at launch, ends up tracking somewhere in-between.

In other news, the PS5 has already outsold the entire PS3 generation in under five years. It has a couple of years left to beat the PS4 globally. I don‚Äôt think anyone‚Äôs ever beating the PS2. Not even the Nintendo Switch.

But my favorite sales data point of all from last month is Final Fantasy Tactics: The Ivalice Chronicles. It came in ninth overall, and second on Switch, which is extra impressive when you remember it‚Äôs selling for only $50. Square Enix hinted at a possible sequel if it does well enough, or at least more strategy RPGs. I‚Äôm buying everyone I know a copy for Christmas.

item.title: I Hope My Outer Worlds 2 Companions Really Do Try To Kill Me
item.content:encoded:
Companions in the original Outer Worlds were kind of stiff. You could build up your relationships with them. They‚Äôd tell you when they were unhappy. But none of it ever led anywhere. They amounted to a fire-suppressing peanut gallery that helped you learn about and reflect on the world around you but little more. The Outer Worlds 2 will try to fix that. You still can‚Äôt romance companions in the sequel but at least they‚Äôll try to kill you this time if you really piss them off.

You‚Äôll have six optional companions in Obsidian‚Äôs upcoming sci-fi RPG, many associated with particular in-game factions. Niles is an engineer from the Earth Directorate. Valerie is a robot from the same faction. Aza is a cultist from the Glorious Dawn. Inez is a field medic from Auntie‚Äôs Choice. Marisol is an assassin from the Order of the Ascendant. Finally there‚Äôs Tristan from the Protectorate who has a giant hammer. Hurt their friends or break their rules and they‚Äôll turn on you.

‚ÄúOne of the things that was really important is we wanted these characters to feel like they‚Äôre their own people,‚Äù design director Matt Singh said on the latest episode of the Xbox Expansion Pass show (via Gamesradar). ‚ÄúThey have their own goals, their own motivations, and if the player‚Äôs aligning with them, that‚Äôs great. They‚Äôre going to be there for you. They‚Äôll fight alongside you. But if you go against their interests, they‚Äôre going to have something to say about it. That might break out into a conflict, that might mean they leave you or you have to fight them to the death. But if you do build that relationship with them, they‚Äôll be there for you in the end.‚Äù

This sounds neat and builds off one of the most memorable moments from the original Mass Effect in which two of your squadmates clash, resulting in an unreconcilable showdown. Over a decade later I still remember what choice I made during that part of the game and why (fuck you, Ashley). I don‚Äôt expect The Outer Worlds 2 to rise to the same level since these confrontations don‚Äôt sound like pivotal scripted moments so much as procedural consequences.

Singh also suggests you can sort of skate by the friction if you have a good enough relationship with the NPC. Something like, ‚ÄúUh, sorry I wiped out your clan, remember that time I finished your second loyalty mission though?‚Äù I hope that‚Äôs not the case. I hope we have some real friends-to-enemies journeys out there in Halcyon this time around. One of my biggest complaints with party-based RPGs is that the people you‚Äôre with never seem to quite have a mind of their own outside of sassy retorts and disappointed scowls. It sounds like The Outer Worlds 2 is trying to evolve the formula beyond that.

‚ÄúWe still wanted to make sure that the player has choice‚Äîmeaningful choice‚Äîhere,‚Äù Singh told RPGSite in another interview. ‚ÄúCompanions are completely optional. If you don‚Äôt want to engage with them, you don‚Äôt have to. But you can take them along and see how that changes your story. Same thing with factions, right? The factions are there. They have their goals. They have their motivations. You can try to side with them. You can try to bring them together. Or you can say, ‚ÄòF it. I‚Äôm going my way. I don‚Äôt care about you. We‚Äôre going to do it the way that I would like.‚Äô We‚Äôre all trying to figure out how to give the player as much player agency as possible and respond to it in interesting ways.‚Äù

item.title: The 15 Funniest, Darkest Things Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A NPCs Have Said To Me
item.content:encoded:
Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A has no business being as funny as it is. Whether I‚Äôm enjoying the absurdity of its main cast‚Äôs antics or passing by an NPC who says something so out of pocket I have to do a double take at their speech bubble, I‚Äôm getting plenty of chuckles out of my time in Lumiose City. The citizens of the Paris-inspired setting seem to be going through it, and it means that you‚Äôll find a lot of odd one-liners popping up as you run through the city. 

There‚Äôs much to be said about whether or not Lumiose City feels ‚Äúalive‚Äù in Legends: Z-A, as the small map‚Äôs lack of distinct districts and visual identity has come under fire since the RPG launched last week. Still, you can‚Äôt deny that its people have character. The main cast of Z-A Royale participants and members of Team MZ are some of the most memorable characters Game Freak has put in one of these games. While the nameless denizens of Lumiose City you encounter aren‚Äôt decked out in glitz and glamour like the members of the main cast, they make the most of their screentime, like that one lady in the background of Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness. 

Some of the brief quips you‚Äôll see while running around actually drop surprisingly insightful tidbits, like revealing what‚Äôs happened to characters from Pok√©mon X and Y. Others are just the ramblings of mad people at their wits‚Äô end, who can‚Äôt be bothered to mask their discontent in front of a group of young adults tirelessly trying to save the city.
